comments.commentBody:
I have to say that the ACA has provided some needed changes to coverage, including more options for the indigent and no longer denying people with pre-existing conditions coverage oronly offering exorbitantly priced coverage. There also are people who are able to orchestrate low annual incomes to qualify for inexpensive ACA plans despite being asset rich, but they are the exception.

There is further good news that overall health care costs have increased minimally for ACA insurance during the past 2-3 years. BUT, that’s where it ends.

During the 2014-16 period my annual insurance premiums - admittedly offered by my company as a retiree benefit - have gone up 25%-25%-20% annually while out-of-pocket maximums have risen substantially. However, to purchase a comparable plan via my state's Healthcare exchange, the cost would be 80% + more.

I don't want you to think I am complaining, but it is a canard to say that Obamacare is going to cost less. The fact is, the costs have been shifted elsewhere in the system so insurers can be made whole.

We may find at some point in the future that by covering more people and helping those needing medical care get their medical issues and recommended lifestyle changes addressed to ensure better overall health, the cost of health care may, in fact, drop substantially for society.

I was kicking myself when the S of "elis" was my last square to fill, and I saw what was meant. This because, while I worked on my first grad degree, Jodie Foster was in residence across the street as one of a few rather famous undergrads (Superman's little brother Joe was there, too); and when I picked up my terminal degree, Ms. Streep was picking up her honorary doctorate. We marched only a few dozen people apart. She was quite pregnant at the time, and radiant was the only way to describe her. Still, as MTF implies, Yale was incredibly stingy with both "Eli" and "Yalie," along with membership in Mory's, reserving them only to undergraduates in Yale College. Yale has since repented of these positions to the point of spreading the ill-considered story that it was never so (this sentiment has even appeared in the "independent" alumni magazine). Anyway, I wish wish wish Eli did not appear so frequently in these puzzles, or if it must, if it could every once in a while be a Hebrew prophet.

BTW, MTF, that would be the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies (FES), est. 1900. During the 80s and 90s, the Dean of FES had a voice that was extremely deep and booming and that voice, combined with his grizzled looks, earned him a huge cheer every year at graduation when he presented the candidates to the President for their degrees.

Ethel, I disagree.  I believe the "small donor" will raise enough money for Bernie to take on whatever Republican is nominated.  And, unlike his opponent, he has very high positives and low negatives, plus polls better than she does beating any of the Republicans running.  Plus, high turnout favors the Democratic Party- the enthusiasm is with Bernie, not Clinton.  Feel the Bern!

Love this! Although degrees are less common in my rural county of 60/40 blue/red, we are hard group to guess. We're not very racially diverse, but very politically and economically diverse. No one advertises to us. Our primary is usually unnecessary (I rarely vote in it) because the earlier voters have always picked a winner before May.

Most Republicans this part of IN have either stated they will vote Trump because they want "change." Many could do what they usually do - vote Democrat just to vote against Clinton.

@Amy :

Your comment made laugh. Try living in the Lone Star State and see what stereotypes are hurled in your direction :) Independents or liberals from Texas? Impossible!

My goodness, I have two post-graduate degrees yet it appears I am a moron by definition, as are David Letterman, Kurt Vonnegut and, ahem, Will Shortz.

By the way, Governor Pence was roundly booed when he threw the first pitch at the AAA baseball game the other day. You see, he's just too conservative. I believe the writer is mistaken about Indianapolis as was noted in other comments. Stereotypes of any kind are quite limiting. I would cross party lines and vote against a GOP candidate in May but there are too many for this feeble brain to pick from.

and Elke
Mac Knight
We are sorry to read that you are not doing as well as hoped.
Our thoughts and prayers will go with you and your whole family.
Keep up your spirits. We are all rooting for you.
l
Way to stereotype an entire ethnicity...

The Rebuilding Center in Portland has responded sensibly to the unfortunate epidemic of old home demolitions. They provide demo services, harvest everything recyclable, charge the developer a fee and then issues the developer a charity deduction.

Most of us here for any time would prefer that Portland was the sleepy midsize town we came to fifteen years ago for a genuine frisson of cool, very affordable housing, and a culture of civilized hedonism (in the very broad sense of enjoyment). Now rising RE values are creating a bonanza for an insurgent class of migrant workers distinct from the so called creative class celebrated only one decade ago. The new employees of startups founded here or moving here can be seen crowding the chic watering holes in newly-densified neighborhoods on Monday night. Money is the face of the new Portland, covered with composite shingles and Bundy Board.
And big pieces of Edmonton and Calgary as well...

Sanders spent 25 years paid by the government and sponsored just 3 bills - two renaming post offices.

I think the American taxpayer was ripped off paying Sanders $5 million over 25 years for naming post offices.
And how many are Chinese McMansions??  Canada needs to re-examine the laws allowing foreigners to take over local housing markets!

"The houses are small by modern standards and old, built in the early to mid-20th century in a booming suburb of Victoria, British Columbia, where eager buyers are now clearing the land to make way for new construction"

TRANSLATION: The "ancient" homes aren't huge, gaudy, or vulgar enough for the new-money uber-rich, who are "clearing the land" to build (no doubt, badly constructed) McMansions!
pnut, congress has most certainly acted by voting down the dream act, not once, not twice, but four times. They've done their job. Now it's time for the president to either enforce the law or resign.
I agree wholeheartedly and thank you for your post.  We have truly lost our way.  Generosity has left us; mean spiritedness has taken over.

It sounds like you don't appreciate the value of self-sufficiency.  Just what do you think will happen if you can't grow your own food and must import every?  You're far more vulnerable is what happens!

Right, self-sufficiency... as it is, our vegetables come from California and Mexico and all sorts of places. The farms in our particular area are mostly small hobby farms, not something we are depending on for survival. No, the land freeze is the consequence of romantic thinking by socialists who think that government is the solution to all problems. Except that it costs you more.

"But of course where you can afford to move after you sell is crucial and a lot of people are not capable of thinking that far ahead."

The condescension of the left never ceases to amaze me. So you think there is a large population in your area who are too stupid to realize they will have to move after they sell their house? Wow.

Victoria, BC's housing market has its own problems.

Foreign money buying houses is driving prices higher similarly to what is happening in San Francisco and many other cities: extremely wealthy individuals wanting to own local real estate for whatever reason are bidding house prices up hundreds of thousands of dollars over the asking price.

Local officials and the local newspaper observe slack-jawed with no real appreciation for what pricing workers out of housing means for the local economy. Being wowed by how big the numbers are is pathetic, but it seems the best home owners here can do. I guess they are calculating how much their own homes are worth. But of course where you can afford to move after you sell is crucial and a lot of people are not capable of thinking that far ahead.

The other problem is an out-of-town property management company buying up several highrise buildings containing hundreds of affordable apartments and renovating them for no good reason beyond being able to raise the rents on them by 40% or more, a busy-work enterprise meant solely to produce a return on money unimaginably wealthy people loan to companies like this to make money on their money.

The days of an economy designed to provide shelter and other necessities to a population, if that's the way it ever was, are long gone.
I'm curious: do you check the immigration credentials of the local hoodlums in your neighborhood in order to make such an unequivocal statement? How exactly do you go about doing this?
When they don't speak English it's a pretty good indicator.

A couple of years ago, an illegal family of Mexicans moved into our neighborhood. This was unusual as we have no local hispanic population and are 1200 miles from the Mexican border. However, we welcomed them (not knowing their illegal status nor asking about it). They were sweet and friendly, as photogenic as the family in the recent article here about illegal families hoping to take advantage of President Obama's despicable edict....there were married parents, a sweet old grandma and 5 cute children ages 5-12.

One night, we awoke to the sound of sirens and police cars. They were at the home rented by the Mexican family. Turned out, the adults in the family (yes, even granny!) were directly involved in the drug trade. The house was chockfull of drugs and I do NOT mean "a few marijuana plants". They had cocaine, heroin, Oxycontin and worse there. They were dealing to the kids in our neighborhood. The home was a locus for drug crime, and also fencing stolen goods.

And as I said: this was an adorable family with cute kids. Face it, anyone who would steal into a foreign country IS A CRIMINAL. They all need to be deported and ASAP.

A lot of comments about illegal immigrants being "hard working" and making our Nation better.  In fact, especially in my neighborhood, most illegal immigrants are involved in the drug trade or are petty criminals.  They have made my neighborhood worse and more dangerous.
You did not notice that he had given his company to his employees?

Too funny!  From your link (which referenced a Pew survey) only 35% of those who identify as Republican or lean Republican agree with the statement that "immigrants today strengthen the country because of their hard work and talents."  Why on earth would any sensible person disagree with that statement?  The U.S. has always been a nation of immigrants.

Its time for a little consistency.  We can either treat them like we do the Cubans and give them instant amnesty.  Or we can put an end to the "special treatment for the Cubans."  Since he is so opposed to any special path to citizenship, why not have Ted Cruz introduce such legislation?
Dream on.

“It’s as if the president is defining the policy and the Congress is executing it,” Justice Kennedy said. “That’s just upside down.”

And there you have it, the real issue at hand. Immigration is just the wrapper to make presidential over-reach acceptable to those who would scream the loudest were it another issue and another party in the Oval Office.
he can't. it's nonsense

Your link goes to a 19-minute clip. The entire Stade 2 piece, reported by Thierry Vildary, is on YouTube at channel "CH TV" and is 24 minutes in 2 parts. Basically it ends with the inventor Varjas showing his earlier, heavier, non-electromagnetic assist from circa 1998, whose efficacy depends on "a high pedaling cadence". Then back to the studio for some innuendo. What was kind of strange is that the reporters ventured to Budapest to visit the inventor and get his show-and-tell, yet they didn't bother with a test drive of the bike equipped with the super-expensive electromagnetic rear wheel. Instead, we see Contador's mechanic, his Bluetooth wristband and antics.
There are golf balls out there with optimized dimples. Search for the Polara.

Varjas says it's a strange market in that people don't admit they have this kind of bike. Uh, just like steroids and celebrity plastic surgery?

The idea that at team uses a $30k system just to train is ludicrous. Next thing, they'll be introducing a new version that thwarts all the detection approaches, for an additional $15k.

That said, I'm glad this technology is being developed. I rode a friend's assist bike in Kyoto, just a family bike with a child seat. It was great. I plan to get an electric bike at some point in the not too distant future, and hopefully there will be technological trickle-down.

But the idea that these bike systems that are hidden are anything other than a cheater's paradise is crazy.

Insurance companies should be completely eliminated. They have no purpose other than to make money and collude with health care providers (mostly greedy hospitals) to make lots of profit together. Create universal health care. Ban paying privately for care. Gov't should set a fixed, low price for each service and stick to it. Single payer all the way.
Perhaps.  Yet, it seems cheaters are usually uncovered and experience humility.  Even those who cheated on your third grade spelling and grammar tests.
